review.title: Bisimulations for fuzzy automata
review.abstract: Bisimulations have been widely used in many areas of computer science to model equivalence between various systems, and to reduce the number of states of these systems, whereas uniform fuzzy relations have recently been introduced as a means to model the fuzzy equivalence between elements of two possible different sets. Here we use the conjunction of these two concepts as a powerful tool in the study of equivalence between fuzzy automata. We prove that a uniform fuzzy relation between fuzzy automata $\cal A$ and $\cal B$ is a forward bisimulation if and only if its kernel and co-kernel are forward bisimulation fuzzy equivalences on $\cal A$ and $\cal B$ and there is a special isomorphism between factor fuzzy automata with respect to these fuzzy equivalences. As a consequence we get that fuzzy automata $\cal A$ and $\cal B$ are UFB-equivalent, i.e., there is a uniform forward bisimulation between them, if and only if there is a special isomorphism between the factor fuzzy automata of $\cal A$ and $\cal B$ with respect to their greatest forward bisimulation fuzzy equivalences. This result reduces the problem of testing UFB-equivalence to the problem of testing isomorphism of fuzzy automata, which is closely related to the well-known graph isomorphism problem. We prove some similar results for backward-forward bisimulations, and we point to fundamental differences. Because of the duality with the studied concepts, backward and forward-backward bisimulations are not considered separately. Finally, we give a comprehensive overview of various concepts on deterministic, nondeterministic, fuzzy, and weighted automata, which are related to bisimulations.
histories: 38 pages, submitted to Fuzzy Sets and Systems
review.COMMENTS: 38 pages, submitted to Fuzzy Sets and Systems

metadata.title: Bisimulations for fuzzy automata

sections.text: In many areas of computer science, the equivalence of these two concepts is used as a powerful tool in the study of equivalence between fuzzy automata. We prove that a unified fuzzy relationship between fuzzy automata A and B is a forward bisimulation if and only if your kernel and its co-kernel are forward bisimulated fuzzy equivalence relationships on A and B, and there is a special isomorphism between fuzzy automata in relation to these fuzzy equivalence relationships. Consequently, we get this fuzzy equivalence of automata A and B as equivalent, i.e. there is a unified forward equivalence between these fuzzy equivalence relationships.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The study of fuzzy automatons and languages was initiated in the 1960s by Santos [95-97], Wee [103], Wee and Fu [104], and Lee and Zadeh [58]. From the late 1960s to the early 2000s, mostly fuzzy automatons and languages with belonging values in the Go-del structure were studied (see for example [25, 33, 74]). The idea of investigating fuzzy automatons with belonging values in some structured abstract categories comes back to W. Wechler [102], and in recent years, researchers have focused mainly on fuzzy automatons with belonging values in fully residued languages, lattices, and other types of lattices. Fuzzy automatons were first investigated by D.W. Qiu in [83, 84] where some basic concepts were discussed, and later D. W. Qiu and his collaborators have conducted extensive research on these fuzzy automatons.

sections.heading: 3. Fuzzy automata
sections.text: In this paper, we examine fuzzy automata with member values in complete residuated lattices. In the rest of the paper, unless otherwise stated, LetL is a complete residuated lattice and letXbe a (finite) alphabet. A fuzzy automaton over L and X, or simply a fuzzy automaton, is a quadrangle A = (A, δA, σA, τA), where A is a non-empty set of A, called the set of states. A · X · L is a blurred subset of A · X · A, called the blurred transition function, and σA: A → L and τA: L are the blurred subsets of A, called the blurred end states and the blurred end states. We can interpret A (a, x, b) as the degree to which an input letter X causes a transition from a state.

sections.heading: 7. UFB-equivalent fuzzy automata
sections.text: There is no real equivalence between two automata if either state is not equivalent to another automata. In other words, equivalence should be modeled by a complete and surjective relationship or, in the fuzzy context, by a surjective relationship. However, if there is a forward bisimulation between two fuzzy automata A and B, which is a surjective L function, then the largest forward bisimulation between A and B also has this property, and according to Theorem 5.8, it is a uniform forward bisimulation.

sections.heading: 8. Backward-forward bisimulations
sections.text: In this section, we will deal with heterotypical bisimulations, and our main goal is to identify similarities and fundamental differences between homotypical and heterotypical bisimulations. However, according to Lemma 5.5, a blurred relationship is a backward-forward-bisimulation between blurred simulations A and B, if and only if there is a forward-backward-bisimulation between the reverse automata A and B. Consequently, for any universally valid statement about backward-forward-bisimulation A and B, there is the corresponding universally valid statement about forward-backward-biblical simulations B, and subsequently we will only have backward-forward-biblical bisimulations. Also, if it is a forward-backward-biblical-type bisimulation, let us note that we are one between blurred automata A and B.

sections.heading: 9. Related concepts
sections.text: It is well known that deterministic automata have a natural interpretation as algebras, in which each input symbol is realized as a universal operation. (This interpretation, advocated by J. R. Buchi and J. B. Wright as early as the late fifties, is used by other authors to define automatisms, and congruences are used in the reduction of the number of states. (Closely related to homomorphisms and congruences are relative morphisms, relationships between two different algebras that are compatible with algebraic operations.) Relational morphisms were introduced by Tilson [31, chapters 11 and 12] in the theory of semigroups to solve some problems related to the decomposition of the wreck, but they have also been found to be useful in the study of languages.

In concurrency theory, bisimulations were introduced by Milner [71] and Park [76] as a means for testing behavioural equivalence among processes, but they have been also very successfully exploited to reduce the state-space of processes.

In concurrency theory, bisimulations were introduced by Milner [71] and Park [76] as a means for testing behavioural equivalence among processes, but they have been also very successfully exploited to reduce the state-space of processes.
However, a more suitable concept has appeared recently in [19], the concept of a uniform relation, and in the fuzzy framework the concept of a uniform fuzzy relation.

The original intention of the authors in [19] was to introduce uniform fuzzy relations as a basis for defining such concept of a fuzzy function which would provide a correspondence between fuzzy functions and fuzzy equivalence relations, analogous to the correspondence between crisp functions and crisp equivalence relations.
In [19], uniform fuzzy relations were employed to solve some systems of fuzzy relation equations, systems that have important applications in approximate reasoning, especially in fuzzy control.

Then in [41], they were used to define and study fuzzy homomorphisms and fuzzy relational morphisms of algebras, and to establish relationships between fuzzy homomorphisms, fuzzy relational morphisms, and fuzzy congruences, analogous to relationships between homomorphisms, relational morphisms, and congruences in classical algebra.
In numerous cases this can be done effectively using the algorithm developed in [21].
Section 4 contains a different presentation of some results from [19] on uniform fuzzy relations, aswell as some new results on these relations.

Emphasizing their monoidal structure, in some sources residuated lattices are called integral, commutative, residuated l-monoids [38].
For other properties of complete residuated lattices we refer to [7, 9].
For other properties of complete residuated lattices we refer to [7, 9].

The most studied and applied structures of truth values, defined on the real unit interval [0, 1] with x ∧ y = min(x, y) and x ∨ y = max(x, y), are the Łukasiewicz structure (where x ⊗ y = max(x + y − 1, 0), x → y = min(1 − x + y, 1)), the Goguen (product) structure (x ⊗ y = x · y, x → y = 1 if x 6 y, and = y/x otherwise), and theGödel structure (x⊗ y = min(x, y), x → y = 1 if x 6 y, and = y otherwise).
More generally, an algebra ([0, 1],∧,∨,⊗,→, 0, 1) is a complete residuated lattice if and only if ⊗ is a left-continuous t-norm and the residuum is defined by x → y = ∨ {u ∈ [0, 1] | u ⊗ x 6 y} (cf.

In this sectionwe recall some notions, notation and results from [19], concerning uniform fuzzy relations and related concepts.

A fuzzy relation φ ∈ F (A × B) is called just a partial fuzzy function if it is a partial fuzzy function with respect to E φ A and E φ B [19].
Partial fuzzy functions were characterized in [19] as follows:

A fuzzy relation φ ∈ F (A × B) is called an L -function if for each a ∈ A there exists b ∈ B such that φ(a, b) = 1 [24], and it is called surjective if for each b ∈ B there exists a ∈ A such that φ(a, b) = 1, i.
Perfect fuzzy functions were introduced and studied by Demirci [22, 23].
Perfect fuzzy functions were introduced and studied by Demirci [22, 23].
If, in addition, φ is a surjective L -function, then it will be called a uniform fuzzy relation [19].
The following characterizations of uniform fuzzy relations provided in [19] will be used in the further text.

Let us note that forward and backward bisimulation fuzzy equivalence relations on fuzzy automata were studied in [20, 21, 100], where theywere called right and left invariant fuzzy equivalence relations.

Let us note that forward and backward bisimulation fuzzy equivalence relations on fuzzy automata were studied in [20, 21, 100], where theywere called right and left invariant fuzzy equivalence relations.
In amore general context, some related fuzzy equivalence relations, called right and left regular fuzzy equivalence relations, were studied in [42].

According to the results proved in [20, 21, 100] (see also [42]), any fuzzy automaton has the greatest forward and backward simulations, which are fuzzy quasi-orders, and the greatest forward and backward bisimulations, which are fuzzy equivalence relations.

Bloom and Ésik [10], and Ésik and Kuich [26] defined a simulation between weighted automata A and B as a weighted relation φ : A × B → S (a matrix over S ) which satisfies conditions (61)–(63).
Bloom and Ésik [10], and Ésik and Kuich [26] defined a simulation between weighted automata A and B as a weighted relation φ : A × B → S (a matrix over S ) which satisfies conditions (61)–(63).

Simulations were introduced in order to provide a structural characterization of equivalence of weighted automata, and in [26] they were used in the completeness proof of the iteration semiring theory axioms for regular languages.
Under the same name, simulations were studied in [27], and under different names in [4–6, 12, 67, 93].

Béal and Perrin [6] used the name backward elementary equivalence, Béal, Lombardy, and Sakarovitch [4, 5] the name conjugacy, which originates from applications in symbolic dynamics, and Buchholz [12] the name (forward) relational simulation.

On the other hand, a weighted relation φ : A×B → S satisfying (58)–(60) (a forward-backward bisimulation, in our terminology) was called in [6] a forward elementary equivalence, and a surjective function φ : A → Bwhich satisfies (58)–(60) was called in [12] a backward bisimulation.

On the other hand, a weighted relation φ : A×B → S satisfying (58)–(60) (a forward-backward bisimulation, in our terminology) was called in [6] a forward elementary equivalence, and a surjective function φ : A → Bwhich satisfies (58)–(60) was called in [12] a backward bisimulation.

It is important to note that Béal, Lombardy, and Sakarovitch [4, 5] found that a semiring S often has the following property: two weighted automata over S are equivalent (they define the same power series, a function from X to S) if and only if they are connected by a finite chain of simulations.

It is important to note that Béal, Lombardy, and Sakarovitch [4, 5] found that a semiring S often has the following property: two weighted automata over S are equivalent (they define the same power series, a function from X to S) if and only if they are connected by a finite chain of simulations.
Semirings having this property include the Boolean semiring [10], the semiring of natural numbers and the ring of integers [4, 5], etc.
Semirings having this property include the Boolean semiring [10], the semiring of natural numbers and the ring of integers [4, 5], etc.
Semirings having this property include the Boolean semiring [10], the semiring of natural numbers and the ring of integers [4, 5], etc.
An example of a semiring which does not have this property is the tropical semiring [27].

metadata.abstractText: Bisimulations have beenwidely used inmany areas of computer science tomodel equivalence between various systems, and to reduce the number of states of these systems, whereas uniform fuzzy relations have recently been introduced as a means to model the fuzzy equivalence between elements of two possible different sets. Here we use the conjunction of these two concepts as a powerful tool in the study of equivalence between fuzzy automata. We prove that a uniform fuzzy relation between fuzzy automata A and B is a forward bisimulation if and only if its kernel and co-kernel are forward bisimulation fuzzy equivalence relations on A and B and there is a special isomorphism between factor fuzzy automata with respect to these fuzzy equivalence relations. As a consequence we get that fuzzy automata A and B are UFB-equivalent, i.e., there is a uniform forward bisimulation between them, if and only if there is a special isomorphism between the factor fuzzy automata ofA and Bwith respect to their greatest forward bisimulation fuzzy equivalence relations. This result reduces the problemof testingUFB-equivalence to the problemof testing isomorphism of fuzzy automata, which is closely related to the well-known graph isomorphism problem. We prove some similar results for backward-forward bisimulations, and we point to fundamental differences. Because of the duality with the studied concepts, backward and forward-backward bisimulations are not considered separately. Finally, we give a comprehensive overview of various concepts on deterministic, nondeterministic, fuzzy, and weighted automata, which are related to bisimulations.
